TEXT: CARDINAL . Following complaints from ORG ( PERSON national des entreprises de second œuvre ) that large construction firms were engaging in certain illegal practices , GPE 's central government authorities instructed ORG to carry out a large - scale administrative investigation into the conduct of public - works contractors .

CARDINAL . In a memorandum dated CARDINAL DATE the head of ORG DATE a body attached to the Competition and ORG , which on DATE became ORG , ORG ( “ the DGCCRF ” ) – provided the officials responsible at inter - département level with details of the planned investigation into the conduct of roadworks contractors in local tendering procedures . Appended to the memorandum was a list of companies to be inspected , either at their head office or at local branch offices , in CARDINAL départements . The list included the CARDINAL applicant companies .

CARDINAL . On DATE inspectors from the DGCCRF carried out simultaneous raids on CARDINAL companies without authorisation from the companies ' management and seized CARDINAL documents . At DATE , on DATE , they conducted further inquiries with a view to obtaining statements .

CARDINAL . On each occasion the inspectors entered the applicant companies ' LOC under the provisions of Ordinance no . DATE of DATE , which did not require any judicial authorisation . While carrying out the raids , the inspectors seized various documents containing evidence of unlawful agreements relating to certain contracts that did not appear in the list of contracts concerned by the investigation .

CARDINAL . On DATE , on the basis of those documents , the Minister for Economic Affairs , Finance and Privatisation asked ORG ( which became ORG after the entry into force of Ordinance no . CARDINAL - CARDINAL of DATE ) to investigate certain acts which , in his opinion , amounted to collusion between separate firms , artificial competition between firms belonging to CARDINAL and the same group in local tendering procedures for roadworks contracts , and agreements restricting competition in the operation of mixing plants .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG was additionally asked by the head of the DGCCRF to investigate acts of a similar nature . That request concerned CARDINAL companies , including the applicant companies .

CARDINAL . In a decision of CARDINAL DATE , published in the Official Bulletin on Competition , ORG ( ORG , de la consommation et de la répression des fraudes – “ the BOCCRF ” ) , ORG , finding evidence of practices outlawed by the ordinance of DATE and the ordinance of CARDINAL DATE , fined the first applicant company MONEY ( FRF ) , the second ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL,CARDINAL and the third FRF CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE published in the BOCCRF , ORG upheld all those penalties . The applicant companies appealed on points of law .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE , likewise published in the BOCCRF , ORG of ORG quashed the judgment of ORG , on the ground that its calculation of turnover and its assessment of the amount of the fines had had no basis in law . It remitted the case to ORG sitting with different judges .

CARDINAL . At the retrial in ORG , the applicant companies contested the lawfulness of the searches and seizures carried out by the inspectors , without any judicial authorisation , under the DATE ordinance . They relied on LAW .
CARDINAL . On DATE the head of ORG DGCCRF submitted additional observations on behalf of ORG , stating , inter alia :
“ ... I will consider CARDINAL points concerning the investigation procedure ... :
( a ) The inspections carried out under the DATE ordinance should have been judicially authorised in advance , in accordance with ORG ...

( b ) Secondly , the seizures carried out by the DGCCRF officials went beyond the actual purpose of the inspections , in that documents not expressly referred to in the application for the investigation were taken from several companies ' head offices .

... section CARDINAL of Ordinance no . CARDINAL - CARDINAL of DATE is worded in very explicit terms , as it states that in the course of their investigations , inspectors may require the production of , and seize , documents of any kind that are likely to facilitate the accomplishment of their tasks , irrespective of whose hands the documents are in . The distinctive feature of this procedure was that , in contrast to the provisions now in force , which were introduced by section CARDINAL of the ordinance of DATE , the inspections were not carried out under constant judicial supervision . In the absence of any provisions on the matter , it is hard to see what supervisory procedure should have been followed .

... it appears from the provisions of the DATE ordinances that the inspectors were vested with powers of search and seizure which they exercised when carrying out their general task of obtaining evidence . The aforementioned section CARDINAL must be interpreted in the light of section CARDINAL of the same ordinance , by which inspectors were granted unrestricted access to LOC ... ”
CARDINAL . On DATE the differently constituted ORG held , inter alia :

“ ... the administrative investigation was carried out in accordance with section CARDINAL of the aforementioned ordinance . By virtue of that provision , inspectors are authorised to require the production of , and to seize , documents of any kind that are likely to facilitate the accomplishment of their task , irrespective of whose hands the documents are in . They have a general right to inspect documents , reinforced by a power of seizure . Since no search took place in the course of the administrative investigation , the firms have no grounds for arguing that there has been interference with their private life or home in breach of LAW ... ”
CARDINAL . ORG fined the first applicant company ORG CARDINAL , the second FRF CARDINAL,CARDINAL,CARDINAL and the third FRF CARDINAL . The applicant companies again appealed on points of law .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE published in the BOCCRF , ORG dismissed their appeal . In particular , it dismissed their complaint under LAW , holding that “ the administrative investigation ... [ had ] not give[n ] rise to any searches or coercive measures ” .

CARDINAL . At the time of the impugned inspections ( DATE and DATE ) , sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of Ordinance no . CARDINAL - CARDINAL of DATE on the detection , prosecution and punishment of offences against legislation on trade and industry provided :

“ The officials referred to in section CARDINAL ( subsections ( CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) ) may require the production of , and may seize , documents of any kind ... that are likely to facilitate the accomplishment of their task , irrespective of whose hands the documents are in . They shall be entitled to take samples .

Officials from ORG and Prices , the Revenue , ORG and Excise , ORG and ORG may also , notwithstanding professional confidentiality , consult any documents kept by ORG , département and municipal authorities or offices , by public and quasi - public corporations , by institutions and bodies under ORG supervision and by firms and services granted a concession by the ORG , départements and municipal authorities . ”

“ ... The officials referred to in section CARDINAL shall have unrestricted access to shops if the latter do not constitute the trader 's residence , in which case the search may only take place in accordance with the provisions of subsection CARDINAL , and to back - shops , offices , annexes , warehouses , LOC used for processing , production , sales , dispatch or storage and , in general , to any LOC , subject , in the case of residential LOC , to the provisions of the fifth subsection of this section ... ”
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of Ordinance no . CARDINAL - CARDINAL of DATE on free prices and competition , repealing Ordinance no . CARDINAL - CARDINAL of DATE , read as follows :

“ Inspectors may enter any LOC , land or means of transport used for occupational purposes , may require the production of books , invoices and any other business documents and make copies thereof , and may obtain information and explanations by means of a summons or at the scene .
They may request the authority to which they are answerable to appoint an expert to draw up any necessary reports with the participation of all the parties . ”

“ Inspectors may make searches of any LOC and seize documents solely in the context of investigations requested by ORG or ORG , and subject to judicial authorisation by an order of the President of the tribunal de grande instance within whose territorial jurisdiction the LOC to be searched are situated , or a judge delegated by him . Where the LOC are situated within the territorial jurisdiction of several courts and are all to be searched simultaneously , a single order may be issued by CARDINAL of the relevant presidents .
The judge shall check that each application for leave made to him is well - founded ; each request shall contain all information that may justify the search .

Searches and seizures shall be carried out under the authority and supervision of the judge who has authorised them . He shall designate CARDINAL or more senior police officers [ officiers de police judiciaire ] with responsibility for being present at the operations and keeping him informed of their progress . Where they take place outside the territorial jurisdiction of his tribunal de grande instance , he shall issue a rogatory letter , for the purposes of such supervision , to the President of the tribunal de grande instance within whose jurisdiction the search is being made .
The judge may go to the scene during the operation . He may decide at any time to suspend or halt the search .
Against an order referred to in the first subsection of this section there shall lie only an appeal on points of law as provided in LAW . Such an appeal shall not have suspensive effect .
Searches may not be commenced before TIME or after TIME They shall be made in the presence of the occupier of the LOC or his representative .
Only the inspectors , the occupier of the LOC or his representative and the senior police officer may inspect documents before they are seized .
Inventories shall be made and documents placed under seal , in accordance with LAW .
The originals of the report and of the inventory shall be forwarded to the judge who ordered the search .
Items and documents that are no longer useful for establishing the truth shall be returned to the occupier of the LOC . ”
CARDINAL . NORP The domestic case - law at the material time may be summarised as follows .
In the field of taxation ORG rejected section CARDINAL of LAW for DATE , concerning the investigation of income - tax and turnover - tax offences , holding , inter alia :

“ While the needs of the Revenue 's work may dictate that tax officials should be authorised to make investigations in private places , such investigations can only be conducted in accordance with LAW , which makes the judiciary responsible for protecting the liberty of the individual in all its aspects , in particular the inviolability of the home . Provision must be made for judicial participation in order that the judiciary 's responsibility and supervisory power may be maintained in their entirety ... ”
I
With regard to the provisions referred to the ORG , the significance of its decision is clear from a constitutional point of view ...
... the decision of DATE must be examined ... in relation to recognition of the inviolability of the home as a constitutional principle .

... The question on which the ORG was asked to give a ruling was not whether sections CARDINAL , CARDINAL , DATE and DATE of the DATE ordinance were constitutional but whether the powers conferred by those provisions could be extended to tax officials in matters concerning direct taxation and GPE [ value - added tax ] .
The issue under consideration was therefore wholly extraneous to the subject matter of the DATE ordinance and there was no necessary link between the CARDINAL types of instrument .

Obviously , that does not mean that ORG indirectly , by implication , acknowledged the constitutionality of the DATE ordinance . It merely ignored the question . But the principles it set forth in the rest of the decision show that certain rules laid down in the DATE ordinance ... have become incompatible with constitutional law under LAW ( see section PERSON below ) .
II

ORG decision has had the effect of highlighting the fact that several provisions of existing statutes providing for purely administrative searches are incompatible with the constitutional principles it has laid down ...
NORP The existing provisions for purely administrative searches are incompatible with the constitutional principles set out in the decision in issue .
( CARDINAL ) Such provisions , which are exceptions to the general law governing searches , are fairly numerous .
LAW ... And LAW ...
Articles L. CARDINAL and L. CARDINAL of LAW ( Code of Tax Procedure ) ...

Among the most recent provisions , particular mention should be made of those in the CARDINAL ordinances of DATE , which serve as the foundation of the economic branch of the criminal law inherited from the ORG regime .

Sections CARDINAL , CARDINAL and DATE ( referred to above ) of Ordinance no . CARDINAL - CARDINAL allow searches to be made , with a view to detecting economic offences , ... of any premises save residential ones , by numerous categories of officials acting alone , ... and of residential premises by any such officials who have been given special authorisation to that end by ORG , and who must be accompanied by a local council officer or a senior police officer and operate during TIME only .
( CARDINAL ) It is quite obvious that all the provisions examined above are incompatible with the principles laid down in ORG decision .

In the great majority of cases there is no provision for any review by the ordinary courts ( for example , in LAW , LAW as regards searches of LOC other than exclusively residential ones , the ordinance of DATE in the same circumstances ... ) . ”
CARDINAL . A DATE report by ORG gives the following analysis of the relevant domestic law after the events in issue :
“ The right of tax , customs and competition officials to make searches and seizures ” ( Study by PERSON , judge of ORG )
“ ... ( b ) The effect of the decision of DATE is clarified by the provisions that were declared invalid .

... The ORG 's decision has another effect , as all legal writers have observed . The provisions of the DATE ordinance ... would all have fallen foul of the ORG if it had existed when they were promulgated . It was therefore implicitly established that they were incompatible with the LAW . Although they could not be retrospectively declared invalid , it was no longer possible for them to be used as a reference in future .

That is all the truer as the government has seen in the ORG 's decision the same implication of invalidity , again noted by legal writers , with regard to the provisions creating the right to make searches in relation to indirect taxation , customs and economic offences , which have now been repealed and replaced by new ones designed to conform to the ORG 's requirements ... ”
CARDINAL . In its judgment of CARDINAL DATE in ORG ( Joined Cases CARDINAL/CARDINAL and CARDINAL/CARDINAL [ DATE ] ORG Reports ( ECR ) CARDINAL ) , ORG of ORG ) held :

“ CARDINAL . Since the applicant has also relied on the requirements stemming from the fundamental right to the inviolability of the home , it should be observed that , although the existence of such a right must be recognised in the ORG legal order as a principle common to the laws of LAW in regard to the private dwellings of natural persons , the same is not true in regard to undertakings , because there are not inconsiderable divergences between the legal systems of GPE in regard to the nature and degree of protection afforded to business LOC against intervention by the public authorities .

CARDINAL . No other inference is to be drawn from DATE ... Convention ... The protective scope of that article is concerned with the development of man 's personal freedom and may not therefore be extended to business LOC . Furthermore , it should be noted that there is no case - law of ORG on that subject .

CARDINAL . None the less , in all the legal systems of the Member States , any intervention by the public authorities in the sphere of private activities of any person , whether natural or legal , must have a legal basis and be justified on the grounds laid down by law , and , consequently , those systems provide , albeit in different forms , protection against arbitrary or disproportionate intervention . The need for such protection must be recognised as a general principle of Community law . In that regard , it should be pointed out that the ORG has held that it has the power to determine whether measures of investigation taken by the ORG under LAW are excessive ( judgment of DATE in Joined Cases CARDINAL to CARDINAL and DATE to CARDINAL , PERSON and ORG [ DATE ] ECR CARDINAL ) . ”
